awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Behavioral and Neural Mechanisms of Attention Capture by Episodic Long-Term Memory
awd_abstract_narration:
Attention is well known to be critically important for learning and memory but relatively less is known about how attention could be influenced by what one remembers from the past.  With support from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Deborah Hannula will conduct experiments combining eye-tracking with functional MRI to characterize the cognitive and neural processes underlying the capture of attention by episodic long-term memory. These studies will address questions about how long-term memory retrieval, particularly retrieval of negative memory, can influence goal-directed behavior by a) identifying the neural mechanisms that are correlated with memory-based capture, and b) identifying ways to avoid and disengage from such capture.   This project combines memory and attention, two typically separated areas of studies, to investigate attention in the context of memory retrieval.  This integrative approach moves one step closer to gaining an understanding of the highly interactive cognitive processes taking place when the brain operates in the real world. 

Characterization of attention capture by long-term memory is important because in some situations long-term memory retrieval is undesirable (e.g., post-traumatic stress disorder). Identifying the neural mechanisms involved in suppressing or disengaging attention from long-term memory may lead to new developments that could help remediate these symptoms in psychiatric populations. To complement the research objectives outlined above, the PI will also implement an education plan that will provide students and community members with interactive and accessible introductions to cognitive science, with an emphasis on memory and attention.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Distraction can derail our progress when we are trying to accomplish a task or meet a goal. Sometimes, for example, our attention is misdirected to distracting perceptual events in the immediate environment. This might be a loud unexpected noise, an object that has a distinctive color (e.g., a red tulip in a field of white daisies), or the sudden appearance of an object in a previously empty location (e.g., advertising that pops into view during a web search). However, distraction can also occur because we have spontaneously remembered something that is not currently relevant, perhaps because something that is physically present in the environment (e.g., an object, a person) has triggered memory retrieval. The big-picture research objective of my CAREER award was to determine whether, and under what circumstances, information stored in long-term memory might capture our attention and whether we can actively control this process. After having determined that currently irrelevant information stored in long-term memory can capture attention, and finding that control does seem possible in some circumstances, we conducted studies to explore the neural correlates of these processes. These experiments were designed to address questions about the brain areas that are engaged when long-term memories capture our attention and the brain areas that may be instrumental in permitting us to avoid memory-based distraction. To accomplish these goals, we used a variety of methods, including basic behavioral measures (e.g., time to respond to a target object), eye-movement recordings, and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) in healthy young adults.

In several experiments, we found that visual information stored in long-term memory was more likely to capture attention when visual search displays were preceded by the presentation of a memory cue (e.g., a scenic picture, such as a city skyline). These memory cues may trigger the retrieval of a learned associate, a process supported by structures in the medial temporal lobe, and particularly, the hippocampus. The learned associate might be the picture of a person that was presented with that cue (i.e., the city skyline) earlier in the experiment. Participants in these experiments were searching for a target stimulus (e.g., a colored circle, a simple shape) and were specifically told to ignore anything else that was present at the same time. We found that if one of the distracting elements in the search display, something that was supposed to be ignored, had been encoded, and especially if a memory cue had been presented recently, that participants sometimes failed to look directly at, or respond quickly to, the search target. Instead, they looked at the item stored in long-term memory. We have found that these memory-based capture effects occur less often when search targets are defined by color than by shape, which may be because color is an especially powerful attractor of visual attention, and therefore, difficult to compete with. In addition, we have found that participants look at the associates of memory cues even when they have been explicitly instructed to conceal (or hide) their memories. Specifically, when participants have been instructed to conceal memory, they do so successfully in behavioral responses, but they fail to avoid looking at remembered content. These eye-movement-based capture effects are relatively short-lived. Initially, attention is misdirected, but within a few seconds, participants manage to follow instructions and distribute their viewing more evenly amongst display elements. Furthermore, when we give participants very specific strategies for controlling memory (e.g., think about a different studied item following the presentation of a memory cue), they seem to be able to avoid capture altogether. Importantly, different subregions of the prefrontal cortex (PFC) seem to be engaged depending on how exactly memory control is accomplished. Specifically, we have found that dorsolateral PFC is more active when participants attempt to actively suppress retrieval and that ventrolateral PFC is more active when participants choose something else (something different from the associate) to focus on instead. In sum, our results suggest that information stored in long-term memory can capture our attention, but a specific plan for avoiding distraction may permit us to keep our attention on task. One possibility is that the strength of a memory representation in the hippocampus determines whether that information takes priority in oculomotor centers of the brain and effectively wins the competition for attention. We are actively exploring this possibility with our neuroimaging data.

 


Last Modified: 09/23/2022
Modified by: Deborah E Hannula
